div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo

div.head: PAN ISLAMIBM IN NORTH AFRICA
div.p: It is a considerable period since the question of North Africa occupied the minds of European statesmen as it is doing to day, and yet it is a region which has from the beginning of h story played a great part in world politics. After a period of stagnation followed by the imposition of foreign ttutelage there are now evidences that we are entering on a fresh stage Hubert i the North African States have been subjected to partition, they have succumbed to European rule,and have been pawns in the game of European polities Now the pawns begin to show signs of life, nod the feet that we cannot trace the galvanising agency makes the situation difficult England in Egypt, and France in Algiers end Tunis, have similar problems to face in the control of large Mohamedan populations. The last few months have been prolific in small and apparently disconnected “incidents” is how for these incidents are real y sporadic or bow far they point to some new force working within their Mohamedan subjects. Of course, says the ' Morning Post," the situations are not altogether parallel; Egland does not ‘rule" Egypt, but the responsibility is the case of England in Egypt is just as real as that of France in the French colonies of North Africa. It it the prestige of Europe, of Christianity, and of Western civilisation which are at stake when the authority of France or England in North Africa is questioned. It is, therefore, with double interest that the telegrams regarding the Franco-Turkish dispute most be read. Is this another Tabah incident? The local circumstance do not seem in any way to warrant each in outrage as the hoisting of the Turkish instead of the French flag. Djanet has not even the possible importance of Tabah from he point of view of the development of future communications, and the whole "incident" coming so soon after the other attempt to enforce Turkish sazsrainty at the expanse of European dignity, is too significant to be awed over as an official indiscretion, although some such explanation may ultimately be given.

The crux of the situation, whether in Tripoli, or (a few months since) in Morooco, undoobtdly lies in the attitude of the Porte, first towards its Mohamedan subjects, and second towards the one great European Power which has no Mohamedan subjects. Pan-Islam mmay be vague, unrealisable, unorganised, but it is a force in Africa to-day such as has not been felt since the palmy days of the Caliphates. The Porte may not be able either to inspire pr control the Pan Islam movement, but it can move the machinery for its own purposes at times. No one who has watched the course of events in the last few years can be unaware of the manner in which this’ machinery is set to work whenever the Porte eels that European diplomacy is besoming rather inconvenient. The policy has become more daring recently under the patronage of a Power which has hitherto not been directly concerned in Turkish affairs. It is an open secret that this Power now desires a position on the Asiatic Continent and fresh spheres of expansion in which the countenance of Turkey will afford her great assistance. She has won that countenance chiefly, perhaps, because her ambitions seem to the astute Turk an excellent foil for other Great Powers who have hitherto regarded the sphere over which lie Porte holds sway as their own special preserve.

This question of preserves is now, if we are to believe the utteranoe of certain German writers, to be raised all along the line. It was raised in Morocco and "settled" there, more with a view to establishing precedents than or any obvious advantages gained by Germany, t is by no means impossible that the Egyptian lit oat ion may furnish grounds for another intervention, the broad lines of the German argument being that an agreement between two Powers does not necessarily bind the others, and that the "open door” demands an international basis in all countries which are more or less dependent on one another. In the particular instance of Djanet the issue raised is a dual one. First, there is the parade of Turkish sexerainty over Tripoli—the Porte is anxious to keep its political position before the eyes of North Africa-and, second, there is the challenge to France. It is not necessary to dig any daeper or far-fetched motives—these two cover the whole situation efficiently u far as the Porte is concerned. But the raising of such questions and the complicatioos which may ensue have deeper and more far reaching effect, than appears on the surface, both in Europe and in Africa as well as in the Near East. In the hands of skilful diplomatists such incidents as these are the material out of which important developments may be shaped. An embarrassing imbroglio on the Franco or Anglo Turkish borders would furnish fresh opportunities for the honest broker, or, as in Macedonia, for the impartial friend ind wall wisher of the Porte.

It is not necessary to credit Germany with my sinister or Machiavellian policy in all this, and is playing for her own hand, and the circumstance which have saved her from becoming mistress of Mohamedan States have given her a lever in dealing with the Porte which England and France cannot, in the nature of hinge, possess. We are obliged every day to our the dislike and distract of the whole Mohamedan world simply because, even with be bast intentions and the most satisfactory results, we can never persuade any peop’l to be without discontent or discomfort under the ale of foreigners of another religion to their own. We are accustomed to assert that no Christian will live under a non Christian Government, and an equally strong prejudice lists in the world of Islam, which we are exists outraging every day. Tbs policy of pinpricks, which stems to be the latest adopted by the Porte, is, therefore, bound, to ] sympathetically regarded not only by be Moslems concerned but by the whole -arid of Islam. We cannot afford to allow bate pinpricks to be successful, though it will be possible to preserve our national dignity without the means and tbs dll to assert ourselves if necessary. The situs Ion is not confined to the aspirations of the strength and the growth of fanaticism in Islam, t is merely another phase of that European struggle in which the attacking party is the young and vigorous German Empire. The Porte and Pan Islam are regarded as pawns in the game, but they display an occasional independent activity which must embarrass the operators. The recent friendly feeling established between England and France strengthens our hope (not only in her interests bet in toss of Great Britain) that the wider issues e have indicated will not be raised in an rote form on the present ocassion. and that in is interests of peace a modus vivendi may be di covered. Despite the optimism of the promonera of The Hague Conference it is hard to see how such a modus nruodi can be reached unless the Moslem world continues to feel that respect for Europe which only military efficiency can command. The peace of Europe is, in fact, threatened by a for greater peril than if "yellow one," and that, as the German Emperor himself remarked recently, it the “Red Peril," the spirit of anti-militarism which now gaining ground in several European States.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Plague. To day 's plague bulletin records a fatal case and a death in Alexandria.
A Bourse rumour. It is rumoured that one of the largest Cairo hotels has been sold for £600,000.
Turkish Subscription. The Turkish subscription opened for the canalization of the Ain Zobeida at Mecca has thus far realised 78,000 liras.
The Brindisi Mall. The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.0., Alexandria, at 9 p m. to-morrow.
The French Malt. The Messageries steamer which arrived from Marseilles today did not bring any mails from London, the connection with the steamer having probably been missed.
Murdered for a Pair of Stirrups. A native of Mit Kbaquan, Shibin al Korn mark z, has been arrested on the charge of murdering his servant, owing to the latter having lost the stirrups of his donkey.
Hashish Smuggling The captain of the Greek S.S. Dzakaki confiscated 20 kilos of hashish in his vessel and handed the drug over to the Customs authority, on his arrival at Alexandria.

Veterinary School The course of classes at the Veterinary School will commence on October 1, but admission will data from September 25. An examination in English is required by Art. 3 of the school regulations.

Pro Russia. The Comitato Pro Libertate Russa have arranged for a gala performance in aid of their funds at the Alhambra Theatre on Thursday next. The programme will include the one act drama. II Artiglio and II Carnevale di Torino, in both of which Signor Novelli will appear.

Drowning Accident. A sad case of drowning is reported from Rhoda Island. Two Greek youths, sons of a well known tobacconist named 1 Panaghiotu, attempted to swim across close to the bridge. One of them succeeded, but not without difficulty, in reaching the further shore; his brother, however, was swept away by the stream, and disappeared.

Wife Murdered in Bazaar. A shocking crime was committed in the bazaar of Tahta the other day, when a native, meeting his wife, plunged a dagger into her j heart and would have decapitated the corpse as well had the bystanders not intervened. He is now awaiting trial. The assassin declares that he murdered his wife because she had deceived him.

Attack on European. Three of the Arabs concerned in the attack on a clerk of the Agricultural Bank at Cairo. a week ego, have been arrested The assault was committed in the Shereb Pen el Herat, and the aggressors number ter, who would have probably de patched the clerk had it not been for timely intervention. As it was, the unfortunate man got a severe thrashing.

Brutal Aggression. The Pyramids road, Cairo, was the scene the other night of a brutal attack on two Europeans, who had gone for a donkey ride. They were attacked next to the "Rendez Vous des Chnsaenm,” that little roadside inn so familiar to tourists and they were found the next morning lying unconscious on the road. Their condition is serious. The aggressors are unknown.

England in Egypt. “The Nation,” of New York, says "England is battening down a fire in the land of the Pharaohs, and after striving earnestly for two decades tor its regeneration, finds hermit compelled, on the twenty fourth anniversary of the bombardment of Alexandria, to increase largely her garrison of European troops. Boast of Anglo-Saxon prowess as you may, it has never yet fought or governed its way into the ejections of a subject people.”

An Egyptian Hair Restorer Accordieg to a medical publication, one of the more ancient heir restorers, as inscribed to an Egyptian papyrus consisted of a mixture of dog, pews, dates, and arses hoofs ground up and cooked in oil, “the bead to be rubbed rigorously with the preparation.” The modern prescription is supposed to be different, but the method of application appears to be the same. What is really wanted in there days is a hair restorer which you can eat with your drink or drink with your food.

Free Employment Registry Office. The Societe Internationale des Employs- , Alexandrie has opened an employment re wry which is absolutely free. A circular has been sent round by the society to obtain admission to the society employees •ton admissioa to the sod sty employes (1) have worked at last six months in Alexandria (2) have good reputation, and (3) be provided With good certificates. The society, which is doing excellent work, deserves the support of all employers of labour.

Alhambra Theartre JriVM Novell' takes his benefit to night, when be will si pear in It 4r!U (“The Ironmaster"). The eminent actor’s stay is drawing to a close, and lovers of the drama should not miss tonight's performance On Sunday next the boards of the comedy company with a very extensive repertoire, which includes Triplicate, La Dama sup Candices, Le Billet de Logement, L’Assommoir L’Arlésienne, Le Contrôleur des Wagons Life, etc.

div.head: GREEK AND BULGAR. FEARED ANTI-GREEK MOVEMENT.
div.p: FREQUENT FIGHTS IN BULGARIA Constantinople, AugUst 13. Greek circles aRe perturbed for Fear oF an anti-Greek movement, not merely as the outcome of facial hatred, but of the uuderstanding between Bulgaria and Rumania. The intention is attributed to Bulgaria of following the Rumanian example by applying a prohibitive tariff on Greek imports. (Reuter)

Sofia, August 13. Frequent fights have occurred between Bulgarian and Greeks. The latest took place at Anchialos, in Bulgaria, where a large part of the town was burned. The Greek Metropolitan is reported to have perished in the flames. (R.)
Constantinople, August 13. The Ecumenical Patriarch has handed a protest to the Ambassadors against the anti Hellenic movement in Bulgaria. (Havas)

div.head: THE MAD MULLAH AGAIN! RAID ON RAKBHARON TRIBE
div.p: London, August 18. The "Daily Man's" correspondent at Aden reports that the Mad MuHah has made a raid on the Rareharon tribe in the Ogaden region, and killed over 1,000 tribesmen and captured 10,000 camels. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SULTAN’S ILLNESS
div.p: HIS MAJESTY’S SUFFERINGS RELIEVED Constantinople, August 13. The Palace physician, by the use of simple appliances, but greatly relieved the sufferings of the Sultan, whose illness is aggravated by renal and urethral complications. (Reuter)

Priate advices received from Constantinople confirm the news of the Sultan’s serious state of health. It is alleged that his Imperial Majesty is really suffering from cancer, to which malady his father and grandfather fell victims We give the news, however, under all reserve.

div.head: FRANCE AND ABYSSINIA
div.p: M. ROZIS COMMERCIAL MISSION Paris August 13. The members of Monsieur Rozi’s commercial mission to Abyssinia will shortly start for Jibuti taking samples of French manufactures. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPAN AND CHINA
div.p: CUSTOM HOUSE FOR DALNY. Peking, August 13 Japan has informed China that everything is ready tor the establishment of a Custom House at Dalny, and urges that similar arrangements should be made at the frontier stations in North Manchuria in order to place the traffic on Japanese and Russian railways on an equality. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEW PERSIA.
div.p: LONDON’S PERSIAN COLONY London, August 13. At a reception of the members of the Persian colony at the Legation, the Charge d’Affaires read a telegram from the Grand Vizier announcing the convocation of an Assembly. He delivered a speech dealing with the high aims of the Shah for the welfare and enlightenment of his people. The members of the colony sent a telegram to the Grand Vizier thanking the Shah for his gracious benevolence and praying that he may enjoy long life. (Reuter)

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL
div.p: By kind permission of Major C.J. L Davidson D.S.O. commanding, and officers 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the String Band will play during dinner on the Terrane of the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday from 8 to 11 p.m.

div.head: THE CALIPHATE. CONSIDERED AS HONORARY TITLE
div.p: TURKEY AND THE POWERS. (Gazette’s Special Service.)

London, Tuesday, August 14. Prince Sabah ed Din, a nephew of the Sultan, in an important letter to Sir Edward Grey on the subject of the Pan Islamic movement, says that until quite recently the Ottoman Sovereigns accounted the Caliphate as merely an honorary title, and it was most sparingly used. It is only recently that the Sultan has attached any importance to his spiritual authority, but he has never looked upon the Caliphate from the point of view of the true disciples of Pan-Islamism Turkey needs keeping on correct if not friendly terms with all the Powers, and she cannot advocate the formation of a league between Mussulman peoples without compromising herself with those nations having Mohamedan subjects.

div.head: SULTAN'S ACCESSION DAY FETES.
div.p: The Fetes Committee for the celebration of the anniversary of the accession of H.I.M. the Sultan Abdul Hamid II. has held several meetings at the house of H.R. Ahmed Pasha Faik. ex Moudir of Gharbieh, and has decided as follows—
Owing to the resignation of H.E. Osman Pasha Ghalib from the presidency of the committee. H.E. Ahmed Pasha Paik was elected in his place.
Mohamed Massoud, one of the editors of “Al Minbar,” was appointed secretary of the committee.
The fete will be given as in the past. The receipts, after deducting expenses, will be devoted to charitable institutions to be selected later.
The Egyptian public will be asked to participate in the fete and to send their subscriptions to the president at the following address: “H.E. Ahmed Pasha Paik, Rue Madaress, Helmet Guedideh, Cairo.”
Officers and men of the Egyptian Army and of the Army of Occupation will be admitted tree, if in uniform.
Invitations will be sent to the Consular Corps, the clergy, and the Press, native and European.

div.head: HELLENIC AGENCY
div.p: A contemporary names M Papadiamentopoulos as the successor to M. Gennadis, Hellenic diplomatic Agent at Cairo.

Mr Ricakis, secretary general of the Agency, has been selected for a poet at Yannina, but in consideration of the services he has rendered to the Hellenic colony of Cairo, and also in view of his popularity, a movement is sure to be made to retain him at his present post.

div.head: MORALITY WAVE
div.p: It is with pleasure that we note the energetic measures taken by the Hellenic consular authorities to wipe out gambling. The last arrest took place on Saturday, the culprit being a certain Dracopoulos, “croupier de tripot.”
In conjuction with Mirali Hopkinson scheme, a wave of morality seems to be sweeping over Egypt, and we trust will have far reaching results.

div.head: DISABLED STEAMER AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The French S.S. Amiral Exelmans (of 3,144 registered tonnage and 2,000 h.p.) arrived at Alexandria this morning from Port Said in tow of two tags. The vessel was on her way home from Saigoa and Siugapore, and on arriving at Port Said an accident to her machinery occurred, which necessitated her coming to Alexandrie to be docked.

div.head: KHEDINIAL MAIL LINE
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Line’s new steamer, the Osmanieh, is to do a trial trip at Newcastle on the 18th inst. This magnificent addition to the fleet of the Khedivial Mail Line is expected to arrive at Alexandria in the first week in September, and will be put on the Greece-Turkey line at an early date.

div.head: THE AUSTRIAN LLOYD
div.p: With a view to facilitating the return of passengers for Egypt from Europe by way of Venice, the Austrian Lloyd Company have established a new line between Trieste and Venice which will be served from Wednesday September 12, until the end of November by the fast steamer Grat Wurmbrand. Sailings from Venice for Trieste will take place every Wednesday at 4 pm , arriving at Trieste at 8.30 pm. Passengers holding tickets for Alexandria will be entitled to have supper on board the Gret Wurmbrand and on their arrival at Trieste they will go direct on board the steamer for Alexandria, where they can spend the night.

The company have also, with the object of shortening the return voyage by the intermediary line, modified the itinerary of this line so that the call at Patras will be done away with and the steamer will arrive at Alexandria early on Thursday evening instead of Friday. Sailings on this line from Trieste will continue to take place every second Friday, and the modification of the itinerary will come into force with the departure from Trieste of Friday, September 14.

div.head: THE CAPE-CAIRO RAILWAY.
div.p: PROGRESS OF THE UNDERTAKING STATEMENT BY SIR CHAS. METCALFE Sir Charles Metcalfe, who is returning to South Africa in connection with the opening of the Broken Hill section of the Cape to Cairo Reilwejr, has made an interesting statement with regard to the progress of the work.

"The line," he said, "is practically finished as far as Broken Hill, and will be opened as soon as the final touches have been put to the Kafue Bridge, which crosses the river of that name and is about the length of Westminster Bridge. This may be expected to be completed next month, and by September there will be a regular service of trains from Capetown for a distance of 2,100 miles to Broken Hill. Fresh rolling stock to the value of £160,000 has been ordered in view of the completion of the railway.

"Beyond Broken Hill the survey is being continued north to the copper mines (a distance of 110 miles), to Buonamaonbwar, on the Congo frontier. Last November when 1 war at those copper mines, about 4,000 feet had been developed, and they seemed to be fairly rich. I visited whole caves of malachite, which are giving about 37 per cent. of copper. These caves are a magnificent sight. Construction work on this section will probably be commenced at an early date."
Dealing with the further extension of the Cape to Cairo route, Sir Charles said:

“At Broken Hill the direct Cape to Cairo line will probably branch off. It will go to the south end of Tangsniyika. The Germans in German East Africa seem to be making a move with their railways, and if we can get our own Government to see that the best business policy is to join up what is called the Uganda Railway with Khartoum.,the Germans making the 60O miles through their territory, the Cape to Cairo scheme will be practically complete. With regard to further railway construction in Africa, my idea is that from Broken Hill a line should go north through the Congo Free State over the high and rich lands, and running north west past Lake Tchad, traversing the French territories, and coming out at Algiers or some other port in the Mediterranean. These will form the two greet railway arteries of Africa one to Cairo, the other to Algiers, and from them will stretch the many branches of East and West Africa. That this will come about I am absolutely certain, and the people who laugh and regard such a scheme as merely a dream, are those who do not realise the enormous possibilities of Africa.”

In conclusion, Sir Charles Metcalfe, when asked to what extent the bequests of Mr. Beit would affect the future of African railway construction, said, "Nothing has yet been settled as to the way in which the money will be employed, but it must necessarily give a very great impetus to railway development."

div.head: ATTACK ON MOUHEB BEY
div.p: Mouheh Bey, the Governor of the Suez Canal, while in his house yesterday, heard a shot fired outside. On enquiring of his orderly he me informed that it was one of several Europeans, passing in a cab, who had fired a revolver. The men were promptly summoned before the Governor, and while his Excellency was questioning them as to why they had discharged firearms in the street, which is prohibited, one of them insulted his Excellency and attempted to assault him, but was cheeked and taken into custody. The man will be brought today before his consular authorities.

div.head: P.W.D. CONTRACTS
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has accepted the tenders eof Mesrrs Khehi Barabet and Sayed Yassin for the supply of stone and the contract of various works entailed in the conservancy of the irrigation canals in the Site Circle and in the provinces of Kalioobheb, Bbarkwh. and Dakshlieh, of the First Irrigation Circle.

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON MARKET
div.p: Messrs Collings Brothers Liverpool, cabled as follows yesterday —
Crop prospects could not be better points to very large crop think we shall be much lower.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS The S.S. Indian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 12th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 28th inst.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKTN.
div.p: MORE WASH-OUTS. DAMAGE TO RAILWAY LINES. (From our Correspondent) Suakin, August 8. The railway line to Atbara is still broken and traffic has been stopped for 13 days. It is liable to be disturbed for another week as fresh wash-outs keep on occurring in fresh places.

On the 4th inst. a very serious wash-out took place also on the Port Sudan line, between Asotriba station and Port Sudan. Bimbashi Newcombe, R.R, Railway Agent, on being informed of this, immediately took a special train with over 100 Berbereen and soldiers. He was accompanied by Mr. Harton, District Traffic Manager, and Mr. W H. Bailey, Inspector of Bridges, Sudan Railway. The party proceeded to the spot where the damage was done and found a great part of the line suspended in mid air over 7 feet high, while the whole of the embankment was washed away. The gang worked all night making a new bank and the line now to Port Sudan is in working order once more.

These wash oats have caused a great deal damage both to the railway and to the merchant’s Train loads of goods and material are waiting to be moved to Atbara and Khartoum and steamers are still bringing in more cargo for the interior of the Sudan.

Attempted Robbery. Last week, some Arab robbers attempted break open the safe at Asotriba station. The telephone clerk, in preventing them, was stabbed and had to be moved to Port Sudan hospital. A police officer, with several policemen, has arrived at Asotriba to investigate the case.
Fire. A serious fire took place at Port Sudan last week in Mr. Lorerzato's ice factory. The building, being of wood, was totally destroyed and the damage done amounts to about £400.

Personal. Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor of the Red Sea Provinces, arrived here on the 6th inst. from England and Suez by the Khedivial Mail Line steamer Mariout, on his return from leave of absence. His Excellency, on landing at the Moudirieh landing stage, was saluted by a guard of honour, the military band being in attendance. Several Sudanese hands (Daiuka) also played to welcome back the Governor, who afterwards distributed some money amongst them. Hawker Bey, after staying home a few days, will go on to Erkoweit, where the Moudirieh headquarters are established during the summer months.

Dr Christopherson, director, Sudan Sanitary Department, has arrived here from Khartoum via Erkowait, where he has been on inspector duty. Owing to the Suakin Atbara line being broken, he will return to Khartoum via Suez, after having inspected Port Sudan.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: STEAMERS FOR PORT SUDAN. (From our Correspondent.) Suez, Monday. The British India steamer Mombasa sailed from Suez yesterday morning for Port Sudan en route to Beira, and was followed this morning by the S.R Langdale and the Dutch steamer Solo, which are also calling at Port Sudan.
Owing to plague at Suez and Port Said several steamers bound for the Continent enter the Canal is voluntary quarantine.
I am pleased to announce that Captain Peel the popular Marius Superintendent for the Khedivial Mail Line at Suez, is now convalescent, and will be able to resume his duties shortly.

div.head: THE BANDMANN COMPANY.
div.p: The Bandmann opera company, which is on its way to Cairo from the Far East, opened a short season in Rangoon yesterday evening. Interviewed regarding his new theatre in Calcutta by the representative of the "Rangoon Times," Mr Bandmann said let me tell you the position of theatrical affair, in Calcutta just now. Up to the present the theatres then have practically been a monopoly- and, who is more, in the hands of foreigners, who charged travelling companies exorbitant rates. The result was that there was no inducement to the better companies to visit the place. This year, when I was in Calcutta, so many difficulties were put in my way that I came to the conclusion to build my own theatre in Calcutta. So I set to work, looked eat far a sit a fount in admirable one right on the Chowrunghes and tendered for it/ The tender was accepted and now I am going to build an up to date theatre as good as ant outside London, and with every modern convenience it will be built of brick and iron, and will hold about 2,000 people. There will be a resident staff of scenic artiste, and a wardrobe with mistress in charge, and resident stage and business managers.

"Then it is my idea be have a regular run of companies out from England. I can tell you now that next year's pieces will be “The White Chrysanthemum,” 'Rise Moon', ‘Mr Popple,' The Little Cherub, The Cherry Girl, Bluebell in Fairyland,’ and the pantomime will be Robinson Crusoe.’ In addition to these I shall have the new Gaiety end Daly', pieces not yet produced in London. I am arranging with the London managers for fortune rights. I hope next year to have two companies—one operatic, one dramatic."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Pasha Ghali has postponed his departure for Europe until Thursday next.

Mr. A. L Webb, C. M. G.. acting Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, who has been in Upper Egypt on a tour of inspection of the irrigation services since the 1st inst., will return to Cairo on the 18th inst.
Dr. Mohamed Pasha Elwi, physician in the service of the Ministry of Public Instruction, has retired on pension after 30 years' service.
Dr. Graham Bey, of the Sanitary Service, has returned to Cairo from a tour of inspection which included Suez and Zagazig.
Constantin Bey Canello, an official in the Persian Consolate-General at Cairo, has resigned his position and entered the service of the Roumanian Diplomatic Agency in Cairo, as an interpreter.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh, we notice : Mr. and Mrs. Debray, Mr. Cassis, Maitre and Mrs. Merc baob. Mr. 8. 0. Abszv. Mr. Miller. div.head: THE SCORPION STONE.
div.p: Scorpions are responsible for a good many deaths in Egypt, and it would be interesting therefore to know whether the “scorpion stone" core is practised by the fellaheen as in India. A correspondent of the “Daily Graphic,” writing on “snake stones." says that, when in India, he was one day with a friend, and not a boy who had been stung by a scorpion. The friend had a scorpion stone, and applied it to the spot where the sting had entered. It adhered to the place, and, after a few momenta, the boy said, “The pain is bets now," indicating a spot lower down the arm. Then he said, “It is bore now," lower still. Till finally, in a moment or two, he said, “The pain is gone," and the stone dropped off. The "stone" requires to be soaked in milk after using. It is in shape and siss like a “French bean," and appears to be made of some composition and to be porous.

div.head: THE ARAB AND POLO.
div.p: Polo has saved the Arab in India from decadeuce, and thus indirectly helped to encourage the breed. The Bombay market, says "Country Life,” is the best in the world for Arab horses, and some of the beat Arabs that leave Arabia find their way thither. But of late years Arab raising in India has been on the decline, and Walers have taken their places as hog-hunters. The Arab is the best of polo ponies for India; bolder than the Australian, less inclined to turn tricky than the country bred, and lasting longer at the game than either, he is in great demand. Except for heavy weight players—and men are always lighter in India than at home—the Arab is the polo pony of the day.

div.head: MOSQUITOES IN LANCASHIRE.
div.p: In South Lancashire, last week, mosquitoes made their appearance in the villages bordering the Ship Canal, between Manchester and Warrington. Numerous residents are complaining of the bites from the insects, which are supposed to have been brought up the canal in timber boats from foreign countries. Mosquitoes have previously made their appearance in the same localities at this season of the year.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

Tenders will be received up to the 30th instant.
They must be made on stamped paper (P T. 3) and sent under double cover, the outside one being superscribed “Postmaster General,” Alexandria, and the inner one “Tender for vans.”
Tenders can be made for all the vans or for any number.
The Administration reserves the right to accept or refuse any tender.
Alexandria, 13th August 1906. 28354-1

Remarques
(De Midi à 1h. p.m.)
Cotons.—Le marché a continué a etre clame et malgré les efforts des haussiers la cloture de la vielle récolte a eu lieu en tendance faible.
La nouvelle récolte est restée calme a la fin.
Graines de coton.—L'Aout a réactionné de 10/40 en cloture et les 3 mois ont perdu 15/40. Le ton est toutefois soutenu.
Féves- Marché nul.
